newsitem.title: FRANCE: Axa buys Generali's 11 percent stake.
newsitem.headline: Axa buys Generali's 11 percent stake.

text.p: Insurer Axa said Friday it bought Italian insurer Generali's 11 percent stake in the French company for 5.9 billion francs ($1.16 billion), bringing down the curtain on their co-operation efforts.
Generali, Italy's largest insurer, sold its Axa stake as it no longer saw it as a strategic holding and Axa exercised its preemptive right to buy the stock, the two companies said.
Generali had long been unhappy over its Axa stake, last year threatening to sell if it did not become a more active partner.

In February, Axa announced a restructuring under which Generali transformed its indirect holding in Axa into a direct holding, making it more liquid. In March, the two signed a shareholder cooperation pact to run unto the year 2000.
"It's true we didn't expect them to sell so quickly," an Axa official said.
The two groups had intended to cooperate internationally with Generali expressing keen interest in developing mutual ventures in Asia where Axa has built a strong foothold.
But these never materialised. "There were no opportunities," said an Axa spokeswoman. Generali said it had nothing to add to the companies' joint statement.
Axa said the purchase eliminated the risk of big amounts of its stock coming onto the market and weighing on the price.
